node.title: Paraview: 1st order variable on 2nd order mesh
node.bodyText:
Hello:
Trying to visualize a 1st order variable on a 2nd order mesh (some vars are 2nd order).  I get unphysical values for the 1st order variables at the 2nd order node locations.  For example:

Is there a setting in Paraview to force interpolation of the variables? (I have asked on the Paraview forum but no response yet). Or do I need to create 2nd order auxvars for my 1st order vars?
Thanks,
Joe Kelly

Hi Joe
I've never seen that.
@roystgnr @dschwen have you / do you have a solution?
Guillaume

I've never seen this either.  I can at least say that "Or do I need to create 2nd order auxvars for my 1st order vars?" isn't the long-term solution - there has to be some kind of bug here.
Is there any way you can reduce the problem to an input file we can use to replicate it?
Thanks.  I'll do that later today.

Besides, I have another two problems. We know that when thermal-mechanical coupling occurs, objects expand as their temperature increases. Correspondingly, the displacement caused by the expansion also affects the distribution of the temperature field. In this case the mesh is actually changing all the time. So how to incorporate the changing mesh into the simulation in MOOSE? Is there any such example in the MOOSE tutorial?
I want to set the inner cylinder to expand only in the radial direction, given constraints in the axial direction. So can I set the boundary conditions like this:
[BCs]
  [./inner_top_no_displacement]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    value = 0
    boundary = 'inner_top'
  [../]
  [./inner_bottom_no_displacement]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    value = 0
    boundary = 'inner_bottom'
  [../]
[]

Hello
I'm not sure about the out of memory error. You could try another LU solver package, and you could try less expensive preconditioners (asm with a lu subpc for example)
You could also try to reduce your memory consumption and see if you can make it work with less elements for example.
For your second question, you just need to specify use_displaced_mesh and set the displacements to turn on displacements for most physics. You should not have to do anything more.
Guillaume

Hi, Guillaume, thank you for your reply.
I used fewer meshes, but moose reported the same error:

                 PC failed due to FACTOR_OUTMEMORY
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_FNORM_NAN iterations 0

 Solve Did NOT Converge!

2layers_3d.zip
So I don't think it's a hardware problem, that is, it's not that the computer's memory is not enough. Do you think MOOSE will reduce the convergence performance due to parallel computing? For example, when a core is used for serial calculation, convergence can be achieved in one iteration. But when computing with four cores, it takes two iterations to reach convergence?
Thank you for advice of use_displaced_mesh, that helps me a lot.

The preconditioning will be different in parallel, so the convergence can be slower. Not with LU iirc though.
You should investigate using different solver packages for LU (with -pc_factor_mat_solver_type strumpack for example), and other preconditioners (asm with a nested pc, ilu)
you may pass a variety of flags to petsc to gain more info about the numerical solve
some of the more commonly used:
 petsc_options = '-ksp_converged_reason -ksp_monitor_true_residual -ksp_monitor_singular_value -snes_converged_reason -snes_linesearch_monitor -snes_view'

I ll refer you to the PETSc documentation for what each of them actually do

Thanks a lot for your kind advice.
I've found that the default of use_displaced_mesh varies in different kernel. When I want to use displaced mesh, should I set use_displaced_mesh = true in each block and kernel which have use_displaced_mesh parameter, such as ADHeatConductionTimeDerivative, ADHeatConduction, DirichletBC ? It seems that I can't set use_displaced_mesh = true in GlobalParams block.
why cant you set in GlobalParams?
MOOSE reports that "The parameter 'GlobalParams/use_displaced_mesh' is a private parameter and should not be used in an input file" when I set use_displaced_mesh =true in GlobalParams block.

ok that must be because there is an object in your input file that does not allow for setting this parameter.
You re going to have to set it object by object then
Yes, I've found ADComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress doesn't allow me to set this parameter. Thank you, Guillaume.

node.title: Coupling Tensor Mechanics with THM Heat Structure
node.bodyText:
Hello friends,
Hopefully this is just a silly mistake by me. I'm trying to use the THM Component "HeatStructureFromFile3D" to import an exodus file to create a mesh for use with some other THM components.
In addition, I'd like to use the Tensor Mechanics module to calculate some the stress/strain from both thermal expansion and an applied load.
Unfortunately, I can not get past the first step of simply getting the Tensor Mechanics module to recognize the mesh. My suspicion is that it's looking for a mesh that technically hasn't been created yet since it is generated by the HeatStructureFromFile3D component after this check. But, I'd love to hear if anyone has any feedback.
Code Snippet:
[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
	[all]
		add_variables = true
	[]
[]


[Components]

	[blk]
		type = HeatStructureFromFile3D
		file = 'GenerateFuelElement_in.e'
		position = '0 0 0'
		initial_T = 372
	[]
[]

EDIT: Forgot to include the error:
*** ERROR ***
No subdomains found

Hello
I dont think THM meshes from components are currently compatible with other modules. @joshuahansel for confirmation
Guillaume

I'm not entirely sure, but I think that this is probably the case. THM was designed to couple with other physics via MultiApps or have the other apps write their own Components. I can at least say that we have no examples of doing what is attempted here.
Hello, Is there any example inputs on coupling THM using MultiApps? Ask this because THM module seems different with others that no [Variables] or [Kernels] is needed in a THM input.

Hello
There's this example on the virtual test bed
https://github.com/idaholab/virtual_test_bed/tree/devel/htgr/assembly
thm.i is the THM input
Guillaume

this is the doc page for it
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/virtual_test_bed/htgr/assembly/index.html
Got it! Thank you Guillaume!

I don't have your input file or stacktrace, but I think the error you're probably hitting is in TensorMechanicsAction. If you want to check the suspicion you have, you can check whether the task THM:build_mesh appears before validate_coordinate_systems when you do Debug/show_actions=true.

Excellent! Thanks for the advice. I'll check this out and report back. I'm a fairly novice MOOSE user and didn't know THM was meant to couple through Multiapps. I'll read up more on Multiapps for the future.

What physical problem are you working toward? You're trying to couple tensor mechanics to a THM heat structure. Does that mean you want to couple to thermal hydraulics? And what kind of coupling between physical domains are you trying to achieve?

Joshua, I apologize for the late reply. I've been on leave.
As I mentioned, I'm new to MOOSE. The goal was to create a model of a NERVA-derived fuel element. The solid domains would have volumetric heating and heat conduction. This solid domain was setup as a heat structure from an exodus file. Then I used heat transfer components to transfer the heat to multiple FlowChannel1Phase components (one for each of the flow channels in the physical fuel element).
I was able to accomplish this. The next step was to see if I could use the results to determine stresses/strains from the thermal expansion combined with an applied load, which is when I ran into problems. I've been learning the MOOSE suite by simply examining examples and trying to mimic them to fit my problem. I had not considered the multi-app functionality and I'm curious if that would solve my issues! When I get a chance, I'll give it an attempt.

node.title: Confusion around FlowChannel1Phase position argument
node.bodyText:
Hi MOOSE team, I am currently using the thermal hydraulics module for a project, and I am a bit confused about the position argument. In step 5 on the single phase flow example, when a second flow channel is added, its position argument on line 214 for the water flow channel is altered slightly to include the thickness of the wall, compared to the helium flow cahnnel. I have included a little drawing to show my understanding of the setup for this set of flow channels and heat exchanger. I don't understand why the position argument requires us to take into account the thickness of the wall, when it has the same "origin" as the rest of the components. My intuition for the geometry may be wrong which would explain why I don't get it, but I was just wondering if there was something else I'm missing. Any help is much appreciated!
Small edit, sorry, realised it was just rude to reference lines on one of the example input files and send anyone answering on a hunt for the correct file. I have attached the relevant file, but the parts I am referring to are this line for the helium flow channel
position = '1 0 2'

and this line for the water flow channel.
position = '${fparse 1 + hx_wall_thickness} 0 2'


example_5.txt
l

Thanks for bringing to my attention @GiudGiud. @TheBEllis Sorry for the confusion in the example. The example does have an annular secondary side channel, and you're right, the axis line segment is what you're usually specifying with position, orientation, and length, so in reality, you shouldn't offset as in the example. The example offsets the secondary side for visualization purposes only: if you were to open up the output file in Paraview without the offset, the primary and secondary sides would be coincident, so the person who wrote the example put the secondary side flow channel just to the right of that intermediate heat structure so that they can be viewed simultaneously instead of having to toggle the primary and secondary side channels on and off. The important thing to realize for this is that few or no cases, this position doesn't actually matter. The only thing that really matters is that you have the channels aligned with other meshes correctly so that nearest node-type couplings work correctly.

Thank you both very much for getting back to me and offering some clarification it was very very helpful! To rack your brains just a bit more, in both the step of the tutorial that @GiudGiud linked, as well as my own input files, I can't actually open the output files in paraview, as it doesn't like the fact that sidesets and element blocks have the same name? Have either of you had any experience of this?

This is an incompatibility with your version of paraview, 5.10.something.
You may either downgrade to 5.9.latest or use the legacy exodus reader in your version

node.title: Hoek-Brown model and Equivalent plastic strain
node.bodyText:
Hi guys,
just wonder does MOOSE have the Hoek-Brown plastic model, I couldn't find it in the document at all (I only see DP and MC models), maybe it's hidden somewhere?
Do we have the 'equivalent plastic strain' or the 'Damage' output for the tensor mechanics module? I guess it's this (below), someone please help me to confirm it.
  [./mc_int_auxk]
    type = MaterialStdVectorAux
    index = 0
    property = plastic_internal_parameter
    variable = mc_int
  [../]

Thank you guys, I hope you have a good day
Traiwit

No Hoek-Brown that i'm aware of.  (I wonder whether a private App has it?)
You are right about the MaterialStdVectorAux.  You just have to be careful with the index, because that depends on your plastic model.  If you are unsure, it's easiest to consult the test files that use the same plastic model that you're using, because they almost always have record plastic strain into AuxVars.  If still unsure, just ask.
a

Hi @WilkAndy, my team has implemented Hoek-Brown in Abaqus, not sure how difficult it is to transfer into MOOSE.
Regarding 'index', I checked several input files, they are all over the place, could you please explain it to me.
If it helps, most of my simulations consider Z-axis to be verticle direction. Should the index be '2' OR I am on the wrong track entirely?
Thank you
Traiwit
Any news on this @Traiwit @WilkAndy

Thanks for prompting, @GiudGiud .
The "index" is nothing to do with direction, @Traiwit .   It is dependent on the plastic model.  For instance, some implementations of Mohr-Coulomb will have 6 yield functions, with each of those functions having a plastic strain associated with them.  Therefore, when using this type of MohrCoulomb you'll have to choose index=0 or index=1, ... or index=5.   On the other hand, another implementation of Mohr-Coulomb will have just 1 yield function (perhaps it has smoothed the 6 mentioned above into one overall surface, or perhaps it does some rearrangement of the principal stresses, or something else) and will have just 1 plastic strain.  Therefore, your only choice is index=0.
So, in conclusion, you have to know the details of the particular implementation of your particular plastic model in order to know what "index" you might be interested in recording.
I suggest you just ask this Discussion list when you're not sure.   Or you can "risk it" and look at test files that use the exact plastic model you're using.

Thanks @WilkAndy
Now i'm more confused with the '6' yield functions, can we control it in the input file?
I think the one I'm using doesn't have the option (TensorMechanicsPlasticMohrCoulombMulti), so index = 0 should be fine

Thanks again guys

You are correct about index=0 @Traiwit .   TensorMechanicsPlasticMohrCoulombMulti does have 6 planar yield functions, so could have 6 plastic internal parameters, but MCMulti actually sums them, so there is only 1.  Hence index=0 is the only valid choice.
(This is not true for other implementations of Mohr-Coulomb.  For instance CappedMohrCoulombStressUpdate has two internal parameters, index=0 corresponding to shear failure and index=1 corresponding to tensile failure.  BTW, it has 12 yield functions, the first 3 being tensile, the next 3 being compression, the next 6 being Mohr-Coulomb.)
For future reference, when you're using the ComputeMultiPlasticityStress with, say
plastic_models = 'model0 model1 model2'

then

index=0 will correspond to the plastic internal parameter of model0
index=1 will correspond to the plastic internal parameter of model1
index=2 will correspond to the plastic internal parameter of model2

Hi @WilkAndy, my team has implemented Hoek-Brown in Abaqus, not sure how difficult it is to transfer into MOOSE.
Regarding 'index', I checked several input files, they are all over the place, could you please explain it to me.
If it helps, most of my simulations consider Z-axis to be verticle direction. Should the index be '2' OR I am on the wrong track entirely?
Thank you Traiwit

Hi @Traiwit ，Recently, I want to use the material subroutines of Hoke-Brown and Mogi Coulomb for comparative tests. I wonder if you can send me the source code of your 's UMAT, 850082649@qq.com
Thank you very much
Sandwish

node.title: Passive scalar transport in THM
node.bodyText: Hello, I wanted to ask, is there a straightforward way to add passive scalar transport into a THM run? Or would it be necessary to rewrite the components so that they support an additional equation to be solved? I couldn't find any answer in the docs/reading through the source code.
@licharlot
THM doesn't support passive scalar. The additional equation for the passive scalar transport would have to be added to the flow model.
We are planning to add a scalar transport module very soon that would build off of Navier-Stokes and THM modules
Thank you for the replies!

node.title: Output automatic scaling factor
node.bodyText:
Hello,
is there a way to output the scaling factor calculated by automatic_scaling?
Alternatively: What I'm doing right now is using extra_vector_tags, a TagVectorAux AuxKernel and a NodalSum Postprocessor to compute the reaction force on a sideset. But the result is affected by automatic_scaling which is why I'm looking for the scaling factor. If there is a better way than the described one that works with automatic_scaling enabled by default, please let me know.
IIRC there is an option in TagVectorAux (#20520) scaled=false that would return the reaction without the scaling factor. But the default behavior should be the one you are describing.
Thanks!

For your first question, yes, you just need to set:
verbose = true
in the executioner block to output the scaling factors
Can only mark one answer, thank you anyway!

Also, whenever I am trying to rebuild petsc , it always says that :

INFO: Checking for HDF5...
INFO: HDF5 library not detected, opting to download via PETSc...

Hopefully, this might help.

I've been following this thread, but I don't have a solution as of yet.
I don't see any influential environment variables which can affect HDF5 runtime (a simple case insensitive grep for hdf5 in env is all I did). @cticenhour may know a little more about HDF5 / PETSc / libMesh combinational (made up word) finds.

It does seem as though you have an HDF5 library somewhere on your machine. Perhaps something to try is, when you run the update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh script, to point it to where HDF5 is located. Based on your logs, I have a guess. Can you try in your moose directory:
HDF5_ROOT=/lib64 ./scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh

If you are using other custom options for your PETSc script, make sure you add those as well (just add in the HDF5_ROOT definition). If this doesn't work, I would find out where the HDF5 library is located and try this approach again.

any news on this?
did it work?

node.title: How to calculate the total free energy in a more accurate way?
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
I was wondering how I can calculate the total free energy in a more accurate way?
The following is the way I used to output the total free energy of the system, but it seems not very accurate? Or do I need to make the simulation become fully converge?
Thank you very much.
# This simulates general particle growth kinetics
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 1
  nx = 2002
  xmax = 6
  uniform_refine = 3
[]

[Variables]
  [./c]
  [../]
  [./w]
  [../]
[]
# aux varaibles to track the free energy change (must decrease with time)
[AuxVariables]
  [./total_F]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
  # the chemical potential gradients
[]

[ICs]
  [./IC_c]
    x1=0
    y1=0
    x2=3
    y2=0
    inside = 1
    outside = -1 # Matrix is supersaturated with solute atoms
    variable = c
    type = BoundingBoxIC
  [../]
[]


# [BCs]
#   [./Periodic]
#     [./cx]
#       variable = c
#       auto_direction = 'x'
#     [../]
#     [./wx]
#       variable = w
#       auto_direction = 'x'
#     [../]
#   [../]
#
# []



[Kernels]
  # Split form of Cahn-Hilliard equation with eta as coupled variable
  # w is the chemical potential
  [./c_dot]
    type = CoupledTimeDerivative
    variable = w
    v = c
  [../]
  [./c_res]
    type = SplitCHParsed
    variable = c
    f_name = F
    kappa_name = kappa_c
    w = w
  [../]

  [./w_res]
    type = SplitCHWRes
    args = 'c'
    variable = w
    mob_name = M
  [../]

[]

[AuxKernels]
  [./total_F]
    type = TotalFreeEnergy
    variable = total_F
    interfacial_vars = c
    kappa_names = kappa_c
  [../]
[]




[Materials]

  [./mobility]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    f_name = M
    args = 'c'
    function = 1
    derivative_order = 1
  [../]

  [./kappa_c]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names  = 'kappa_c'
    prop_values = '8.0e-4'
  [../]

  [./free_energy]
    # equivalent to `MathFreeEnergy`
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    f_name = F
    args = 'c'
    function = 3.2154*c^2*(1.93779-3.96889*c^2+2*c^4)+0.1
  [../]



[]



[Postprocessors]

  [./ElementInt_c]
    type = ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor
    variable = c
  [../]

  [./total_F]
    type = ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor
    variable = total_F
  [../]
[]

# [VectorPostprocessors]
#  # The numerical values of the variables/auxvariables across the centerline
#  [./line_values]
#    type =  LineValueSampler
#    start_point = '0 0 0'
#    end_point = '6 0 0'
#    variable = 'c'
#    num_points = 361
#    sort_by = x
#    #execute_on = 'FINAL'
#  [../]
# []


 ##[VectorPostprocessors]
  # The numerical values of the variables/auxvariables across the centerline
  ##[./line_values]
   ##type =  LineValueSampler
    ##start_point = '0'
    #end_point = '9'
    #variable = 'c w j_tot'
    #num_points = 199
    #sort_by =  id
    #execute_on = 'TIMESTEP_END'
  #[../]
#[]



[Preconditioning]
  # active = ' '
  [./SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  scheme = 'BDF2'
  #petsc_options = '-snes_mf'

  #Preconditioned JFNK (default)
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'

  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_grmres_restart -sub_ksp_type -sub_pc_type -pc_asm_overlap'
  petsc_options_value = 'asm      31                  preonly       lu           1'
  #petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
  #petsc_options_value = 'lu'

  l_max_its = 50 # maximum linear iterations
  l_tol = 1.0e-6 # 0.001 Linear Tolerance

  nl_max_its = 500 # maximum number of nonlinear iterations. exceed will cut dt.
  nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-9 # -8 nonlinear relative tolerance
  line_search = 'none'
  #num_steps = 2

  # [./TimeStepper]
  #   type = IterationAdaptiveDT
  #   dt = 1e-6
  #   cutback_factor = 0.67
  #   growth_factor = 1.5   # 1.6
  #   optimal_iterations = 10
  #   iteration_window = 2
  # [../]

  # [./Adaptivity]
  #   coarsen_fraction = 0.1
  #   refine_fraction = 0.7
  #   max_h_level = 3
  #   interval = 1
  # [../]
  #[./TimeStepper]
    #type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    #dt = 1e-6
    #cutback_factor = 0.67
    #growth_factor = 1.5   # 1.6
    #optimal_iterations = 20
    #iteration_window = 2
  #[../]
  [./TimeStepper]
    type = ConstantDT
    dt = 1e-6
    cutback_factor_at_failure = 0.67
    growth_factor = 1.5
  [../]
  [./Adaptivity]
    coarsen_fraction = 0.1
    refine_fraction = 0.7
    max_h_level = 3
    interval = 1
  [../]


[]

[Debug]
  show_var_residual_norms = true
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  console = true
  csv = true
  interval = 1
  checkpoint = true
  [./console]
    type = Console
    max_rows = 10
  [../]
[]

You have to converge your simulation numerically before examining metrics. The non-linear solve process may visit completely unphysical states before converging
Guillaume
I think there are also a number of other posts on the forum about computing the free energy, you may want to consult them
